div.p: Pronouns: First Persons become αὐτός, αὐτοί, σφᾶς, σφῶν, σφίσιν.
Second and Third Persons become ἐκεῖνος, ἐκεῖνοι, αὐτόν, αὐτούς.
(ἑαυτόν, ἑαυτούς, σφᾶς αὐτούς may refer emphatically to the speaker, or to the Subject of their own Clause. σφέτερος may refer, as Indirect Reflexive, to either.)
οὗτος, οὕτως, νῦν, are generally left unchanged.
Obs. 1.—ἐκεῖνον is stronger than αὐτόν.
Obs. 2.—αὐτοί and αὐτούς must be carefully distinguished in long Oratio Obliqua :

cit.quote: τοῦ δ᾽ ἄλλου λιμένος αὐτοὶ κρατήσειν, καὶ συμφερομένους αὐτοὺς ταράξεσθαι.
We shall be masters of the rest of the harbour, while the enemy will be crowded together and thrown into confusion.

div.p: (Sometimes for clearness a Noun must be substituted, or the Pronoun may sometimes be omitted.)
These rules are illustrated in their order in the following piece :

div.head: (Statement.)
div.p: O. R.—"The enemy are watching an opportunity for battle: they have surrounded the camp, and will soon make their attack: indeed, but for an unforeseen chance, they would even now be upon us."

O. O.—ὁ δὲ στρατηγὸς ἔφη τοὺς πολεμίους καιρόν τε τοῦ μάχεσθαι ἐπιτηρεῖν καὶ τὸ στρατόπεδον κύκλῳ περιεστάναι καὶ προσβολὴν οὐ διὰ μακροῦ ποιήσεσθαι· εἰ μὲν οὖν μὴ ἀπροσδόκητόν τι αὐτοῖς ἐμποδὼν ἐγένετο, ἤδη ἄν σφισιν ἐμπίπτειν.

div.head: (Command.)
div.p: O. R.—"Get ready your arms and think not of surrender. Let us either conquer or die."
O. O.—ὥστε ἐκέλευσεν αὐτοὺς τὰ ὅπλα ὡς ἐπὶ μάχῃ παρασκευάζεσθαι, μηδὲ τὰ περὶ τοῦ ἐνδοῦναι φρονεῖν· χρῆναι γὰρ ἢ νικῆσαι ἢ καὶ ἀποθανεῖν.

div.head: (Question.)
div.p: O. R.—"Why do you hesitate? Does God forget the righteous? What ground have we for fear?”
O. O.—τί δ᾽ οὖν πότ᾽, ἔφη, οὕτως, ὦ ἄνδρες, ἀποκνεῖτε; μῶν γὰρ ἐπελήσθησαν οἱ θεοὶ τῶν δικαίων; ἢ τίς αἰτία ὑπεστιν ἡμῖν τοῦ κατέχεσθαι τῷ φόβῳ;

div.head: (Subordinate Clauses.)
div.p: O. R.—"The man who has espoused the cause of justice need never tremble at death; but whatever shall prove the issue of the day, he will at least not die ingloriously, and will deserve well of his country; who, while the fates allow, cherishes the memory of her bravest citizens to the end of time."

O. O.—ὅτῳ γὰρ ἂν συμπαραστῇ ἡ δίκη, τοῦτον οὐ δεῖν ὀῤῥωδεῖν τὸν θάνατον, ἀλλ᾽, ὅπως ἂν ἐκβῇ τὰ πράγματα, οὐκ ἄνευ γε τιμῆς αὐτὸν ἀποθανεῖσθαι, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἄξια πράξειν τῆς πόλεως· ἥνπερ, ὅσον γε ἔξεστι χρόνον, τοσοῦτον τῶν ἀνδρειοτάτων πολιτῶν ἀείμνηστον τὴν δόξαν ἀεὶ σώζειν.

div.head: (Pronouns.)
div.p: O. R.—"I then will do my part; you, my men, will not fail in yours and desert me at this great crisis; and, as for our allies, they will assuredly prove themselves worthy of the great trust which I have ever placed in them. But, most of all, you, Hipparchus, must be ready to follow me with your cavalry at the given signal."

O. O.—αὐτὸς μὲν οὖν ἔφη ἐκτελεῖν τὰ ἑαυτοῦ, ἐκείνους δὲ τά τε σφῶν αὐτῶν ὑποστήσειν οὔθ᾽ ἑαυτὸν ἐν τούτῳ τῷ χρόνῳ προδώσειν, τοὺς δ᾽ αὖ συμμάχους τὴν πίστιν ἣν ἀεὶ περὶ αὐτῶν ἔχει, ταύτην δὴ νῦν οὐδ᾽ ὁπωσοῦν σφαλεῖν. μάλιστα δὲ ἁπάντων δεῖν τὸν Ἱππαρχον τοὺς ἱππέας ἔχοντα παρεσκευασμένον εἶναι ὡς ἑαυτῷ ἑψόμενον.
οὐ denies facts; μή denies conceptions.
μή is used:
(a) In Main Sentences: Commands, Wishes, Exhortations.
(b) In Subordinate Clauses:
(1) Final Clauses: including Final Relatives, and Clauses after φοβοῦμαι and φυλάσσομαι.
(2) Hypothetic Clauses: including Participles used hypothetically, Indefinite Relatives (ὅστις = εἴ τις), and Indefinite Substantives or Substantival Phrases implying a hypothesis.
(3) The Infinitive (except in Oratio Obliqua).
Otherwise οὐ is used (and οὐ is used, even in the above, where the Negative coalesces with a particular word, and in antitheses).
Note 1.—In Questions nonne expects "yes," num "no"; "or not" is annon, Direct, necne, Indirect.
Note 2.—Where ne is used, neve must be used for "and not"; ne unquam for nunquam, etc.
Instances are given in the Syntax of the Sentence; note also the following contrasts:
Main Sentences :
Non dicat, he would not say (statement).
Ne dicat, let him not say (command).
Subordinate Clauses :
Sic castra munivit ut ea hostes expugnare non possent. He fortified the camp so strongly that the enemy could not take it. (Consequence.)
Sic castra munivit ne ea hostes expugnare possent. He fortified the camp in this way that the enemy might not take it. (Purpose.)
Observe ne with dum, modo, dummodo, provided that :

cit.quote: Dum ne tibi videar, non laboro.
Provided I do not seem so to you, I do not trouble myself.

div.p: Note. In all clauses, Main or Subordinate, where ne is used, neve, ne quid, ne unquam, etc., must also be used; not neque, nihil, nunquam, etc.:
Ne unquam peccaveris, never do wrong.

cit.quote: Curavit, ne quid detrimenti respublica caperet.
He took care that the state should suffer no harm.

div.p: Haud: in the phrase Haud scio an, I almost think; otherwise only with Adjectives and Adverbs:

cit.quote: Haud ignota loquor.
I say what is not unknown.

div.p: Male, parum, minus, as a mild Negative, chiefly with Adjectives and Adverbs—minus also with Verbs: male sanus, not in his senses; parum concinne, not neatly; minus sapiens, not wise :

cit.quote: Nonnunquam ea, quae praedicta sunt, minus eveniunt.
Predictions sometimes do not quite come true.

div.p: So often, Sin minus, as a sentence, but if it is not so.
Obs. 1. “Non” for “ne" (1) coalescing, (2) in antithesis:
(1) Et sit humus cineri non onerosa tuo. OV. And may the earth lie lightly on thy ashes!
(2) Aut non tentaris aut perfice. OV. Either do not try, or succeed.
So neque for neve in antithesis after a Positive:

cit.quote: Transque caput jace nec respexeris.
Cast it over thy head nor look behind thee.

div.p: Obs. 2.—Ne is not used for non except in the phrase ne—quidem, not even, and in compounds, nescio, nequeo, necopinatus, etc.
(Instances of the use of ne for ut non are only apparent. Thus:

cit.quote: Id ne fieri posset, oppidi circummunitione fiebat.
This was being rendered impossible by the circumvallation of the town.

div.p: Ne shows that the result was also Cæsar's object.)
In Poetry there is some licence in the use of non for ne in Direct Commands and Wishes:

cit.quote: Non Teucros agat in Rutulos.
Let him not lead the Rutulians against the Teucrians.

div.p: So, still more often, in the use of neque for neve:

cit.quote: Nemo me dacrumis decoret neque funera fletu faxit.
Let no one honour me with tears, nor celebrate my funeral with weeping. (Faxit = faciat.)

div.p: In Prose nemo also would be ne quis. (On the redundant Negative in neque see § 508.)

div.head: Position of the Negative.
div.p: The Negative is often thrown back on the Main Verb, where in English it is attached to the Subordinate Verb: E.g., nego, I say not (§ 348), not dico non.
The Negative impress is usually stamped on a sentence as soon as possible, e.g., with the copula: neque, and not; nec quisquam, and no one.
But with possum the non is often reserved :

cit.quote: Pompeius munitiones Caesaris prohibere non poterat.
Pompey could not stop Cæsar's circumvallation.

div.head: Repetition of the Negative.
div.p: (1) As a rule, both Negatives count, as in English:

Nemo non, every one; non nemo, some one; nihil non, everything; nonnihil, something; nonnulli, some (non ulli, none); non possum non, I cannot help—; (non modo sometimes = non modo non, not only not).
(2) But redundancy occurs if a Negative is followed by (a) Ne—quidem or non modo:

cit.quote: Quid praeterea sit bonum, negat Epicurus se posse ne suspicari quidem.
Epicurus says he cannot even guess what further good there is.

div.p: (b) Neque—neque, or even one neque :

cit.quote: Nemo unquam neque poeta neque orator fuit.
There was never either a poet or an orator.

div.p: (So, neque faxit, § 503.)
Obs. 1.—Nemo non, non possum non, should be compared with nemo est quin, facere non possum quin (§ 514).
Obs. 2.—Observe ne non after Verbs of Fearing :
Timeo ne non venerit. I fear he has not come.
(See supra, § 371.)

div.head: Quominus.
div.p: Quominus is used with the Subjunctive after Verbs of hindering and abstaining: e.g.,

cit.quote: Non recusabo quominus omnes mea legant.
I shall not object to every one reading what I write.

div.p: Observe the idiom, per aliquem stat quominus :

cit.quote: Per Afranium stetit quominus dimicaretur.
It was through Afranius that no battle was fought.

div.p: Note. These Verbs may also take ne and Subjunctive, or the Infinitive; prohibeo prefers the Infinitive. (With quominus a Negative need not precede.)
Note 1.—In Questions οὐ = nonne, μή = num. μή is also used in Deliberative Questions.
Note 2.—The rules which apply to οὐ and μή apply also to their compounds, οὐδέ, μηδέ, οὔπω, μήπω, etc.
Instances are given in the Syntax of the Sentence; note also the following contrasts:
The Participle :

cit.quote: οὐκ εὐτυχοῦσαι δόξετ᾽ οὐχὶ δυστυχεῖν.
You shall seem to be not unfortunate, though you are not fortunate (fact). (Hence οὐ with καίπερ.)
οὐκ ἂν δύναιο, μὴ καμών, εὐδαιμονεῖν.
You could not be happy if you did not toil (hypothesis).

div.p: The Infinitive:

cit.quote: ἔλεγον οὐκ εἶναι αὐτόνομοι.
They said they were not independent (Oratio Obliqua).
ἔλεγον αὐτοῖς μὴ ἀδικεῖν.
They told them not to do wrong (Indirect Command).
(τὸ μὴ γενέσθαι τῷ θανεῖν ἴσον λέγω.
I account not-to-be-born the same as to be dead. μή, regular Negative with Infinitive.)

div.p: The chief difficulty occurs with Substantival and Adjectival Phrases (with μή an "if" may always be traced):

cit.quote: γράψας τὴν τῶν γεφυρῶν οὐ διάλυσιν.
Mentioning the fact of the non-destruction of the bridge (fact).
δεινὸν δ᾽ ἐστὶν ἡ μὴ ἐμπειρία.
Want of skill is a terrible thing (if anyone wants).

div.p: αἱ οὐκ ὀρθαὶ πολιτεῖαι αὗται. PLAT. These incorrect forms of government (a definite lot).
οἱ μὴ καθαροὶ τὰς χεῖρας. ANTIPH. Those who are not clean-handed (if any are not).
So with Relatives, etc. :

cit.quote: ἃ μὴ οἶδα οὐδὲ οἴομαι εἰδέναι.
What I don't know, I do not think I know (if I don't know).
οὐκ ἔστι τοῖς μὴ δρῶσι σύμμαχος τύχη.
Fortune does not help those who do not help themselves (if they don't, etc.).

div.p: (ἃ οὐκ οἶδα, τοῖς οὐ δρῶσι, would refer to definite things and definite people.)
In all these μή has an Indefinite, Generic force.
Obs. 1. οὐ for μή (1) coalescing, (2) in antithesis :
(1) εἰ ἀποστῆναι ᾿Αθηναίων οὐκ ἠθελήσαμεν, οὐκ ἠδικοῦμεν. THUC. If we were unwilling to revolt from Athens, we were not doing wrong. (μή is usual in "if" clauses.)

cit.quote: (2) κελεύει οὐκ ἐν τῇ ἐκκλησίᾳ ἀλλ᾽ ἐν τῷ θεάτρῳ τὴν ἀνάρρησιν γίγνεσθαι.
He ordered the proclamation to be made not in the public assembly, but in the theatre. (μή is usual with Infinitive.)

div.p: Obs. 2.—μή is sometimes used where we should expect οὐ:
(1) In Oratio Obliqua, regularly with Future Infinitive after ἐλπίζω; sometimes also with Verbs of Perception, e.g., οἶδα. In all these not only a fact, but the mere idea of it is denied.
(2) Often in Indirect Questions after εἰ, including the alternative ἢ μή, or not. This is from false analogy with εἰ, hypothetic.
(Apparent exceptions can usually be explained: e.g., δίδασκέ μ᾿ ὡς μὴ εἰδότα (SOPH.), (Imperative affects it). χρῆν οὐ σ᾽ ἁμαρτάνειν (EUR.), (from the usual οὐ χρή, § 505).

Note.—οὐδείς, μηδείς, οὐδέν, μηδέν, are peculiar. οὐδείς often = “a nobody,” μηδείς of "the dead”; οὐδέν what is really nothing, μηδέν what is practically nothing. Thus, τὸ μηδὲν εἰς οὐδὲν ῥέπει (EUR.). On the whole μηδέν is preferred; but rhythm, metre, etc., often decide alone.

div.head: Position of the Negative.
div.p: The Negative is often thrown back on the Main Verb, where in English it is attached to the Subordinate Verb: E.g., οὐ φημί, I say not; οὐκ οἴομαι, I think not.

The Negative thus sometimes becomes οὐ, where, if left to the Infinitive, it would have been μή: e.g., οὐκ ἀξιῶ, I beg not; οὐ χρή, we ought not; οὐκ ἐῶ, I forbid. But with ὤφελον in Wishes (§ 333) it remains μή:

cit.quote: μή ποτ᾽ ὤφελον λιπεῖν τὴν Σκύρον.
Would I had never left Scyros!

div.head: Repetition of the Negative.
div.p: (1) If a simple Negative comes second, both count:
οὐδεὶς οὐκ ἔπασχε (ΧΕΝ.), everyone suffered; lit., (there was) no one (who) did not suffer.
οὐδεὶς οὐκ and οὐ μόνον οὐ are almost the only instances; for the latter οὐ μόνον is sometimes used.
(2) If a compound Negative comes second, it is redundant:

cit.quote: ἀκούει δ᾽ οὐδὲν οὐδεὶς οὐδενός.
And no one obeys any one in anything.
μηπότ᾽ ἀσεβὲς μηδὲν μήτε ποιήσητε μήτε βουλεύσητε.
Never do or think anything unholy.

div.p: (A redundant Negative sometimes follows οὐ μᾶλλον ἤ :

cit.quote: ἥκει γὰρ ὁ Πέρσης οὐδέν τι μᾶλλον ἐφ᾽ ἡμᾶς ἢ οὐ καὶ ἐφ᾽ ὑμᾶς.
The Persian has come no more against us than you. Cf. Plus vite que tu ne penses.)

div.p: Note. If the Negatives differ in kind, both count: e.g.,

cit.quote: οὐ δύναμαι μὴ γελᾶν.
I cannot help laughing.
φοβοῦμαι μὴ οὐκ ἀληθὲς ᾖ.
I fear lest this may not be true.

div.p: (The uses of μή and μὴ οὐ which follow are exceptional.)

div.head: Redundant μή.
div.p: μή may precede the Infinitive after verbs with a negative idea:
(a) Verbs of preventing and abstaining: e.g.,

cit.quote: θνητούς γ᾽ ἔπαυσα μὴ προδέρκεσθαι μόρον.
I stopped mortals from foreseeing their destiny.

div.p: (b) Verbs of denying, doubting, distrusting, forbidding :

cit.quote: ὁ Πρηξάσπης ἔξαρνος ἦν μὴ ἀποκτεῖναι Σμέρδιν.
Prexaspes denied that he had killed Smerdis.

div.p: Note.—Verbs of Preventing may take (1) Infinitive; (2) μή and Infinitive; (3) τοῦ with Infinitive; (4) τοῦ μή with Infinitive.

div.head: Quin.
div.p: Quin with Subjunctive is used only after a Negative or quasi-Negative (e.g., such words as vix, aegre, "hardly," or questions expecting the answer "no") :
(1) (a) With Verbs of preventing and abstaining (cf. § 510):

cit.quote: Aegre sunt retenti quin oppidum irrumperent.
They were hardly prevented from breaking into the town.

div.p: (b) Verbs of doubting and denying :

cit.quote: Quis dubitat quin in virtute divitiae positae sint?
Who doubts that true wealth lies in virtue?

div.p: So non dubium est, nihil dubii est, quin, there is no doubt that. (Distinguish dubito with Infinitive, I hesitate to do a thing: like timeo with Infinitive.)
(2) Any phrase, when Negatived, may be followed by a Consecutive quin, as an alternative for ut non, "that not":

cit.quote: Nunquam tam male est Siculis quin aliquid facete dicant.
The Sicilians are never in such a bad way that they cannot say something witty.

div.p: Note. Observe the phrases, facere non possum quin, I cannot but; fieri non potest quin, it cannot but be that; nihil abest quin, it is almost the case that :

cit.quote: Facere non possum quin cotidie literas ad te mittam.
I cannot but send you a letter every day.
Nihil abest quin sim miserrimus.
Nothing is wanting to complete my misery.

div.p: (This is the Negative of tantum abest ut, so far from, § 444.)
(3) Observe the phrase, nemo est quin, there is no one who—not:

cit.quote: In castello nemo fuit militum quin vulneraretur.
There was not a man in the fort who was not wounded.

div.p: Obs. 1.—Quin after Verbal phrases, as in (1) and (2), is an Adverb, quî-ne, how not; quin after nemo est, as in (3), is a Relative, qui-ne, who not. In this use it is mainly Nominative, qui-ne, quae-ne, quod-ne: for the Accusative, quem non or quin eum is preferred.
Obs. 2.—Contrast the English of non dubito quin, "I do not doubt that," and nemo est quin, "there is no one that not". In both quin may be translated “but”.
Beside its use with the Subjunctive, quin has other uses :
(1) Quin, why not: Interrogative: usually Present Indicative:

cit.quote: Quin potius pacem aeternam exercemus?
Why do we not rather engage in eternal peace? (For Tense, see § 201.)

div.p: (2) Quin, nay rather: with Imperative:

cit.quote: Quin morere.
Nay, rather die.

div.p: So with Statements, especially in the phrase quinetiam, moreover :

cit.quote: Ausus quin etiam voces jactare per umbram.
Daring moreover to shout aloud through the gloom.

div.head: μὴ οὐ.
div.p: Any Verb which, for any reason, when Positive takes μή with Infinitive may when Negatived take μὴ οὐ.
(1) Verbs which take redundant μή with Infinitive, § 510.
(a) With Verbs of preventing and abstaining :

cit.quote: οὐ δυνατοὶ αὐτὸν ἴσχειν εἰσὶν ᾿Αργεῖοι μὴ οὐκ ἐξιέναι.
The Argives cannot prevent him from going out.

div.p: (b) Verbs of denying, doubting, distrusting, forbidding:

cit.quote: τίνα οἴει ἀπαρνήσεσθαι μὴ οὐχὶ ἐπίστασθαι τὰ δίκαια;
Who do you think will deny that he knows what is right?

div.p: So with phrases like τί ἐμποδὼν μὴ οὐ; What is to prevent, etc.?
(The Questions in these last two are quasi-Negative.)
(2) Any Verb, with μή and Infinitive, where μή means "not": e.g.,
οὗτος μ᾽ ἂν πείσειε μὴ ἐλθεῖν. He would persuade me NOT to come. Becomes, when Negatived:

cit.quote: οὐδεὶς μ᾽ ἂν πείσειε μὴ οὐκ ἐλθεῖν.
No one would persuade me NOT to come.

div.p: In this sense μὴ οὐ occurs with a hypothetic Participle:

cit.quote: δυσάλγητος γὰρ ἂν εἴην μὴ οὐ κατοικτείρων.
I should be hard-hearted if I did not pity (δυσάλγητος, quasi-Negative).

div.p: (3) From these uses must be distinguished μή and μὴ οὐ with Subjunctive, after a Verb of Fearing understood (§ 371):

cit.quote: μὴ ἀγροικότερον ἢ τὸ ἀληθὲς εἰπεῖν.
(I am afraid lest) it may be rather blunt to speak the truth.
ἀλλὰ μὴ οὐ τοῦτ᾽ ᾖ χαλεπόν, θάνατον ἐκφυγεῖν.
(I am afraid lest) it may not be difficult to escape death.

div.p: Obs. Three uses of μὴ οὐ must therefore be distinguished:
(1) (a) and (b), prevent, deny, with Infinitive; both οὐ and μή redundant.
(2) Any Verb, with Infinitive or Participle: οὐ alone redundant. (Allied to (1).)
(3) μὴ οὐ with Subjunctive: neither Negative redundant.

div.head: οὐ μή.
div.p: (1) With the Aorist Subjunctive (less often First or Third Person of Future Indicative) expresses a strong denial :

cit.quote: οὐ μὴ παύσωμαι φιλοσοφῶν.
I will assuredly not cease the pursuit of philosophy.
(ἀλλ᾽ εἴσιθ᾽· οὔ σοι μὴ μεθέψομαί ποτε.
But enter: I will never follow thee.)

div.p: (2) With the Second Person Future Indicative, Interrogative, expresses a strong prohibition (οὐ may be continued to a second Clause) :

cit.quote: οὐ μὴ προσοίσεις χεῖρα, μήδ᾽ ἅψει πέπλων;
Do not lay hand on me or touch my robes (sc. οὐ μὴ ἅψει).

div.p: (Here οὐ μή is the Negative form of οὐ: e.g., οὐ πράξεις; will you not do it? i.e., do it! οὐ μὴ πράξεις; will you not not-do it? i.e., do not do it!)
Obs. The Subjunctive use may be employed in Prose; the Future Indicative, in both senses, is poetic. (See Excursus, § 600.)

div.head: 1. Alliteration.
div.p: The repetition of the same consonantal sound: e.g., "The wisdom of many and the wit of one":

cit.quote: O Tite tute Tati tibi tanta tyranne, tulisti?
O Titus Tatius, hast thou taken so much on thee, thou tyrant?

div.p: Distinguish "Assonance"—the repetition of the same vowel sounds (see inf., § 542, “Paronomasia'").

div.head: 2. Analogy.
div.p: "Comparison": e.g., an Intransitive Verb often takes an Accusative, on the "analogy" of another Verb, which is Transitive:

cit.quote: Ardebat Alexin.
He loved Alexis (sc., amabat).
So Ardet abire fugâ
he burns to fly (sc., cupit).

div.head: 3. Anakoluthon
div.p: (An, "not"; akoloutheo, "follow"). "Non-sequence" of construction. This is especially common with the Nominativus Pendens—Nominative without a Verb:

cit.quote: Galea alta Chimaeram sustinet, efflantem ignes, tam magis illa fremens.
His lofty helmet bears the Chimæra, breathing flames, but now raging yet the more.

div.head: 4. Antiptosis
div.p: Or Attic Construction (anti, "before"; ptosis, "falling"). The "anticipation," as Object in the Main Clause, of a Noun which is Subject in the Subordinate Clause :

cit.quote: Nosti Marcellum, quam tardus sit.
You know Marcellus, how slow he is. (Cf. in English: “I know thee who thou art”.)

div.p: (This construction is not so common in Latin as in Greek.)

div.head: 5. Antithesis
div.p: (Anti, "against"; tithēmi, “I set”). The contrast of "opposites," whether in two clauses or in one. In clauses Latin usually omits the Conjunctive Particle :

cit.quote: Solitudinem faciunt, pacem appellant.
They make a solitude and call it peace.

div.head: 6. Aposiopesis
div.p: (Aposiopao, “I am silent"). The sudden cessation of a Sentence before its conclusion: e.g., "Bertrand is what I dare not name" (SCOTT).

cit.quote: Quos ego—sed motos praestat componere fluctus.
I'll soon—but now I must allay the troubled flood.

div.head: 7. Asyndeton
div.p: (A, "not"; syndeo, "bind together"). The omission of the Conjunctive Particle: cf., "Ah, miserable, false, unkind, untrue!" (TENNYSON); see further § 325:

cit.quote: Abiit, excessit, evasit, erupit.
He departed, he went out, he hastened out, he dashed out.

div.head: 8. Attraction.
div.p: The "drawing" of one word into the construction of another: see under Attraction, §§ 551-558: also Optative, § 345.

div.head: 9. Brachylogy
div.p: (Brachys, "short"). The suppression of part of a phrase especially common in comparisons (Comparatio Compendiaria) :

cit.quote: Aetas parentum pejor avis.
The age of our fathers worse than (that of) our grandfathers.

div.head: 10. Chiasmus
div.p: (Greek letter chi: X). The cross-wise arrangement of contrasted terms, so that the means and extremes correspond respectively together :

cit.quote: Ratio consentit, repugnat oratio.
Reason consents, but rhythm is opposed.

div.head: 11. Constructio ad sensum
div.p: (Sense-construction: see infra, § 559).

div.head: 12. Ellipse
div.p: (Elleipsis, “omission”). The omission of a word: e.g., "St. Paul's" (Cathedral); "out with thee!" sc., "go out":
Ad Vestae, to Vesta's (temple); calda, sc., aqua, warm water.
So entire clauses may be omitted, e.g., in Wishes: "If only this were true!" (sc., I should be glad). But explanation of construction by ellipse should be regarded with caution.

div.head: 1. Alliteration.
div.p: The repetition of the same consonantal sound: e.g., "The wisdom of many and the wit of one":

cit.quote: Σῶσος μὲν σωθείς, Σωσὼ δ᾽ ὅτι Σῶσος ἐσώθη.
Sosos being saved; Soso, because Sosos was saved.

div.p: Distinguish "Assonance"—the repetition of the same vowel sounds (see inf., § 542, “Paronomasia'").

div.head: 2. Analogy.
div.p: "Comparison": e.g., an Intransitive Verb often takes an Accusative, on the "analogy" of another Verb, which is Transitive:

cit.quote: κίνδυνον ὑπεξέστη.
He avoided danger (sc., ὑπέφυγεν).

div.p: (So ἔχω λέγειν, sc., δύναμαι λέγειν.)

div.head: 3. Anakoluthon
div.p: (An, "not"; akoloutheo, "follow"). "Non-sequence" of construction. This is especially common with the Nominativus Pendens—Nominative without a Verb:

cit.quote: λόγοι δ᾽ ἐν ἀλλήλοισιν ἐρρόθουν κακοί, φύλαξ ἐλέγχων φύλακα.
Hard words were bandied among them, guard blaming guard.

div.head: 4. Antiptosis
div.p: Or Attic Construction (anti, "before"; ptosis, "falling"). The "anticipation," as Object in the Main Clause, of a Noun which is Subject in the Subordinate Clause :

cit.quote: ἀνήρετ᾿ ἄρτι Χαιρεφώντα Σωκράτης ψύλλαν, ὁπόσους ἄλλοιτο τοὺς αὑτῆς πόδας.
Socrates asked Chaerephon the other day about a flea, how many of its own feet it jumped.

div.head: 5. Antithesis
div.p: (Anti, "against"; tithēmi, “I set”). The contrast of "opposites," whether in two clauses or in one. Greek generally points the antithesis with μέν and δέ:

cit.quote: λόγῳ μὲν δημοκρατία, ἔργῳ δὲ ἀρχή.
In theory a democracy, in reality a despotism.

div.head: 6. Aposiopesis
div.p: (Aposiopao, “I am silent"). The sudden cessation of a Sentence before its conclusion: e.g., "Bertrand is what I dare not name" (SCOTT).

cit.quote: εὐδαιμονοίης, Τηλέφῳ δ᾽ ἁγὼ φρονῶ.
To you all happiness! to Telephus—I won't say what I think.

div.head: 7. Asyndeton
div.p: (A, "not"; syndeo, "bind together"). The omission of the Conjunctive Particle: cf., "Ah, miserable, false, unkind, untrue!" (TENNYSON); see further § 325:

cit.quote: εὕδομες εὖ μάλα μακρὸν ἀτέρμονα νήγρετον ὕπνον.
We sleep well that long, unending, unawaking sleep.

div.head: 8. Attraction.
div.p: The "drawing" of one word into the construction of another: see under Attraction, §§ 551-558: also Optative, § 345.

div.head: 9. Brachylogy
div.p: (Brachys, "short"). The suppression of part of a phrase especially common in comparisons (Comparatio Compendiaria) :

cit.quote: κόμαι Χαρίτεσσιν ὁμοῖαι.
Hair like unto (that of) the Graces.

div.head: 10. Chiasmus
div.p: (Greek letter chi: X). The cross-wise arrangement of contrasted terms, so that the means and extremes correspond respectively together :

cit.quote: ἡδονὴ βραχεῖα μακρὰν τίκτει λύπην.
Brief pleasure breeds long pain.

div.head: 11. Constructio ad sensum
div.p: (Sense-construction: see infra, § 559).

div.head: 12. Ellipse
div.p: (Elleipsis, “omission”). The omission of a word: e.g., "St. Paul's" (Cathedral); "out with thee!" sc., "go out":
εἰς Ἅιδου, to (the house of) Hades; οὐκ ἐκτός (sc., εἶ); away!
So entire clauses may be omitted, e.g., in Wishes: "If only this were true!" (sc., I should be glad). But explanation of construction by ellipse should be regarded with caution.

div.head: 13. Epithets (Special uses of).
div.p: Passive for Active: cf. Milton, "The sleepy drench of that forgetful lake," of the effect produced :

cit.quote: Rugosum piper.
Wrinkled pepper.

div.p: Active for Passive: cf. Shakespeare, “Upon the sightless couriers of the air" (viz., unseen) :

cit.quote: Merentes poenas.
Deserving punishments.

div.p: Compound Adjectives are specially variable in this way:

cit.quote: Velivolae naves.
Sail-flying ships.
Velivolum mare.
The sail-flown sea.

div.p: Attributive Epithet: viz., Adjective for Possessive Genitive; cf. "Above the flight of Pegasean wing" (MILTON) :

cit.quote: Hectoreum ad tumulum.
At Hector's tomb.

div.p: Literary Epithet: giving the place most famous for a thing:

cit.quote: Hyblaeis apibus.
Bees of Hybla.

div.p: On "Transferred Epithet" see Hypallage, § 534; on the Proleptic use of Adjectives see Prolepsis, § 545.

div.head: 14. Hendiadys
div.p: (Hen, "one"; dia duoin, “through two "). The expression of a Noun and Attribute by two Nouns and a Copulative Conjunction:

cit.quote: Pateris libamus et auro.
We pour from golden cups.

div.head: 15. Hypallage
div.p: (Hypo, allasso, "change"). The transference of an Epithet from one word to another; or the interchange of construction between two words:
Nemeaeus hiatus leonis. LUCR. (I.e., Hiatus Nemeaei leonis.)
Sese tulit obvia mater. VIRG. (I.e., Sese tulit obviam.)
Dare classibus austros. VIRG. (I.e., Dare classes austris.)
Cf., "With the innumerable sound of hymns and sacred songs" (MILTON). (This use is also called Metathesis.)

div.head: 16. Hyperbaton
div.p: (Hyper, "over"; baino, "go"). The trespassing of a word from its own phrase or clause into another:

cit.quote: Ajax cum immeritos occidit desipit agnos.
Ajax is mad while he slays the harmless lambs.

div.p: Hyperbaton is specially common of the Personal Pronoun in adjurations:

cit.quote: Per te deos oro.
I entreat thee by the gods.

div.head: 17. Hysteron Proteron
div.p: ("Last first"). The placing first of an idea which is last in point of time: cf. "I die, I faint, I fail" (SHELLEY), (also called Prothusteron):

cit.quote: Moriamur et in media arma ruamus.
Let us die and rush into the midst of the battle.

div.head: 18. Litotes
div.p: (Leios, "smooth"). Rhetorical understatement. Frequent in colloquial English: "just a little," i.e., very much.

cit.quote: Illaudatus Busiris.
Unpraised Busiris (viz., accursed).

div.head: 19. Metaphor
div.p: ("Transference”: Translatio verborum (CIC.)). The transference of a term from its literal meaning to one derived—especially from a physical to a mental sense:

cit.quote: Mens exaestuat irâ.
The mind surges with wrath.

div.p: (A metaphor is, in its first use, a compressed similé; thus "The moon sails across the sky" means literally, "As a ship sails across the sea, so the moon passes across the sky". But when such a phrase has been long absorbed into a language, it almost ceases to be metaphorical; thus "sail" has almost passed into a commonplace for "move".)
A word on the border-land of Metaphor is often qualified by some saving phrase:
E.g., Quasi, tanquam, quidam, ut ita dicam:

cit.quote: Philosophia artium quasi parens.
Philosophy, the parent of all arts.

div.head: 20. Onomatopoeia
div.p: (Onoma, “a name” or "word"; poioumai, “represent”). The representation of sense by sound; e.g., "Myriads of rivulets hurrying through the lawn" (TENNYSON):

cit.quote: Quadrupedante putrem sonitu quatit ungula campum.
His hoof with fourfold trampling paws the soil to dust (of a horse).

div.head: 21. Oxymoron
div.p: (Oxus, "sharp"; moros, "dull"). The combination of conflicting words; e.g., "And faith unfaithful kept him falsely true" (TENNYSON):

cit.quote: Impietas pia.
Pious impiety.

div.head: 22. Paraprosdokian
div.p: (Para, etc., "contrary to expectation"). An unexpected turn to a sentence, especially in the form of a sudden bathos at the end (also called παρ᾽ ὑπόνοιαν):

cit.quote: Nullis aconita propinquis miscuit—Troica non scripsit.
He never mixed poison for his relatives, he never wrote a poem like the Troica.

div.p: This use is common in Elizabethan Poetry: "Where thou, great Anna, whom three realms obey, Dost sometimes counsel take and sometimes—tea”.

div.head: 23. Paronomasia
div.p: (Para, "alongside"; onoma, "word"). The juxtaposition of words of similar sound, especially frequent in proverbs and epigrams (cf. Assonance, § 1):

cit.quote: Urbem fecisti quod prius orbis erat.
Thou hast made into a city what was a world before.

div.head: 24. Periphrasis
div.p: I.e. Circumlocution (N.B. circuitus verborum (CIC.) means a period in Prose).
With Substantives this is especially common of a Noun and Genitive: cf. "The might of Gabriel fought" (MILTON):

cit.quote: Venit et Crispi jucunda senectus.
There comes, too, the genial old age of Crispinus (viz., the old man C.).

div.p: (The "Periphrastic Tenses" (§ 211) are so called as being a circumlocution for the simple tenses.)

div.head: 25. Pleonasm
div.p: (Pleon, "more," i.e., than is required). Redundancy of expression—the use of superfluous words; e.g., "we have seen with our eyes":

cit.quote: Insonuere cavae gemitumque dedere cavernae.
Its cavernous hollows echoed and moaned again.

div.head: 26. Prolepsis
div.p: I.e., Anticipation (pro, "before"; lambano, "take"). The use of an Adjective, Participle, or Preposition, before its sense is due: cf. "So those two brothers and their murdered man Rode past fair Arno" (KEATS). A Proleptic Adjective often expresses the effect of a Verbal Action :

cit.quote: Montes umbrantur opaci.
The hills are veiled in darkness.

div.p: Virgil is specially fond of this use.

div.head: 27. Syllepsis
div.p: (Syllambano, "take together"). The use of a word with two others, to both of which it applies properly but in a different sense (contrast Zeugma): cf. Pope, "This general is a great taker of snuff as well as of towns":

cit.quote: Regnator, coelum et terras qui numine torquet.
The monarch, who rules the (revolving) sky and the land with his divine will. (Coelum torquet, "revolves the sky".)

div.head: 28. Tmesis
div.p: The breaking of a word into two parts (Greek, temno, I cut). This is rare in Latin, but instances occur:

cit.quote: Saxo cere comminuit brum.
He broke his head with a stone (cerebrum comminuit).

div.head: 29. Zeugma
div.p: ("A yoking together"). The use of a word with two others, to one of which alone it applies properly (contrast "Syllepsis"): cf. Pope, "See Pan with flocks, with fruits Pomona crowned" (i.e., surrounded with flocks):

cit.quote: Audis quo strepitu janua remugiat Et positas ut glaciet nives Juppiter?
Dost thou hear how loudly the door creaks, and (see) how the god of heaven turns the fallen snow to ice?

div.head: 30. Certain Metrical and Other Terms.
div.p: A Spondaic Hexameter is one which has a Spondee instead of a Dactyl in the Fifth Foot:

cit.quote: Armatumque auro circumspicit Oriona.
He looks round and sees Orion armed with gold.

div.head: 13. Epithets (Special uses of).
div.p: Passive for Active: cf. Milton, "The sleepy drench of that forgetful lake," of the effect produced :

cit.quote: χλωρὸν δέος.
Pale fear.

div.p: Active for Passive: cf. Shakespeare, “Upon the sightless couriers of the air" (viz., unseen) :

cit.quote: ναυσὶν ἐμπείροις.
Vessels proved by use.

div.p: Compound Adjectives are specially variable in this way:

cit.quote: ἄγελαι βούνομοι.
Herds of grazing kine.
βούνομον ἀκτάν.
A shore grazed on by kine.

div.p: Attributive Epithet: viz., Adjective for Possessive Genitive; cf. "Above the flight of Pegasean wing" (MILTON) :

cit.quote: Τελαμώνιος Αἴας.
Ajax, son of Telamon.

div.p: Perpetual Epithet: e.g., γῆ πουλυβότειρα (HOM.), the fertile earth (used even of level land selected for a chariot-race).
On "Transferred Epithet" see Hypallage, § 534; on the Proleptic use of Adjectives see Prolepsis, § 545.

div.head: 14. Hendiadys
div.p: (Hen, "one"; dia duoin, “through two "). The expression of a Noun and Attribute by two Nouns and a Copulative Conjunction:

cit.quote: βότα καὶ λείαν.
Plundered kine.

div.head: 15. Hypallage
div.p: (Hypo, allasso, "change"). The transference of an Epithet from one word to another; or the interchange of construction between two words:

cit.quote: ὄγκον ὀνόματος μητρῷον.
Motherly boast of a name (i.e., ὄγκον ὀνόματος μητρώου, the boast of a mother's name).

div.p: γραῖαι ὄσσων πηγαί, aged fountains of eyes.

div.head: 16. Hyperbaton
div.p: (Hyper, "over"; baino, "go"). The trespassing of a word from its own phrase or clause into another:

cit.quote: ὥσπερ με τὸν ᾿Αθάμανθ᾽ ὅπως μὴ θύσετε.
Mind you do not sacrifice me like Athamas.

div.p: Hyperbaton is specially common of the Personal Pronoun in adjurations:

cit.quote: πρός νύν σε πατρὸς ἱκνοῦμαι.
I pray thee by thy father.

div.head: 17. Hysteron Proteron
div.p: ("Last first"). The placing first of an idea which is last in point of time: cf. "I die, I faint, I fail" (SHELLEY), (also called Prothusteron):

cit.quote: τὰς μὲν ἄρα θρέψασα τεκοῦσα τε.
Having nourished them and borne them.

div.head: 18. Litotes
div.p: (Leios, "smooth"). Rhetorical understatement. Frequent in colloquial English: "just a little," i.e., very much.
οὐχ ἥκιστα, i.e., μάλιστα, very much.

div.head: 19. Metaphor
div.p: ("Transference”: Translatio verborum (CIC.)). The transference of a term from its literal meaning to one derived—especially from a physical to a mental sense:

cit.quote: πόλις σαλεύει.
The city is tossed upon a sea of troubles.

div.p: (A metaphor is, in its first use, a compressed similé; thus "The moon sails across the sky" means literally, "As a ship sails across the sea, so the moon passes across the sky". But when such a phrase has been long absorbed into a language, it almost ceases to be metaphorical; thus "sail" has almost passed into a commonplace for "move".)
A word on the border-land of Metaphor is often qualified by some saving phrase:
Viz., ὡς, ἅτε, ὡσπερανεί, τις, ὡς εἰπεῖν :
E.g., Σκύλλα τις. A very Scylla.
(Such qualification is not so common in Greek as in Latin.)

div.head: 20. Onomatopoeia
div.p: (Onoma, “a name” or "word"; poioumai, “represent”). The representation of sense by sound; e.g., "Myriads of rivulets hurrying through the lawn" (TENNYSON):

cit.quote: πολλὰ δ᾽ ἄναντα, κάταντα, πάραντά τε, δόχμιά τ᾽ ἦλθον.
Oft up and down, sideways, aslant, they went (of jolting carts).

div.head: 21. Oxymoron
div.p: (Oxus, "sharp"; moros, "dull"). The combination of conflicting words; e.g., "And faith unfaithful kept him falsely true" (TENNYSON):

cit.quote: γάμος ἄγαμος.
A marriage that is no marriage.

div.head: 22. Paraprosdokian
div.p: (Para, etc., "contrary to expectation"). An unexpected turn to a sentence, especially in the form of a sudden bathos at the end (also called παρ᾽ ὑπόνοιαν):
Frequent in Aristophanes:

cit.quote: ἀνὴρ ἀμείνων περί σε καὶ τὴν γαστέρα.
(Sc., τὴν πόλιν.) A man who does better for you and your constitution.

div.head: 23. Paronomasia
div.p: (Para, "alongside"; onoma, "word"). The juxtaposition of words of similar sound, especially frequent in proverbs and epigrams (cf. Assonance, § 1):

cit.quote: παθήματα μαθήματα.
I.e., "one learns by experience" (cf. Eng. "might is right").

div.head: 24. Periphrasis
div.p: I.e. Circumlocution (N.B. circuitus verborum (CIC.) means a period in Prose).
With Substantives this is especially common of a Noun and Genitive: cf. "The might of Gabriel fought" (MILTON):

cit.quote: τοῦ δ᾽ ἤκουσ᾽ ἱερὴ ἴς Τελεμάχοιο.
And the mighty prince Telemachus heard him (lit., "great might of").

div.p: (The "Periphrastic Tenses" (§ 211) are so called as being a circumlocution for the simple tenses.)

div.head: 25. Pleonasm
div.p: (Pleon, "more," i.e., than is required). Redundancy of expression—the use of superfluous words; e.g., "we have seen with our eyes":

cit.quote: πανύστατον δὴ κοὔποτ᾽ αὖθις ὕστερον.
For the last time and never more again.

div.head: 26. Prolepsis
div.p: I.e., Anticipation (pro, "before"; lambano, "take"). The use of an Adjective, Participle, or Preposition, before its sense is due: cf. "So those two brothers and their murdered man Rode past fair Arno" (KEATS). A Proleptic Adjective often expresses the effect of a Verbal Action :

cit.quote: τῶν σῶν ἀδέρκτων ὀμμάτων τητώμενος.
Reft of thine eyes that ne'er shall see again.

div.head: 27. Syllepsis
div.p: (Syllambano, "take together"). The use of a word with two others, to both of which it applies properly but in a different sense (contrast Zeugma):

cit.quote: ἕλεν δ᾽ Οἰνομάου βίαν παρθένον τε σύνευνον.
He o'ercame the might of Oenomaus, and (won) the virgin for his bride.

div.p: (Frequent in Aristophanes.)

div.head: 28. Tmesis
div.p: The breaking of a word into two parts (Greek, temno, I cut). Occurs chiefly with the Prepositions of Compound Verbs :

cit.quote: ἂν δ᾽ Ὀδυσεὺς πολύμητις ἀνίστατο.
And up the wary Odysseus rose.

div.head: 29. Zeugma
div.p: ("A yoking together"). The use of a word with two others, to one of which alone it applies properly (contrast "Syllepsis"):

cit.quote: ᾿Ανδροφάγοι ἐσθῆτα φορέουσι τῇ Σκυθικῇ ὁμοίην, γλῶσσαν δὲ ἰδίην.
The Androphagi wear raiment like the Scythian, but (speak) a language of their own.

div.head: 30. Certain Metrical and Other Terms.
div.p: A Spondaic Hexameter is one which has a Spondee instead of a Dactyl in the Fifth Foot:

cit.quote: ἑσταότες παρ᾿ ὄχεσφιν, ἐΰθρονον ἠῶ μίμνον.
Standing beside the chariots, they awaited the golden dawn.

div.p: A short syllable is sometimes made long in arsi, viz., if the accent of the foot falls on it (arsis, a "raising," i.e., of the voice) :

cit.quote: Dona dehinc auro gravia sectoque elephanto.

div.p: A long syllable is sometimes made short in thesi, viz., where the accent does not fall (thesis, a "lowering," i.e., of the voice) :

cit.quote: Obstipui, steteruntque comae: vox faucibus haesit.

div.p: Sometimes a line, so to speak, overflows. This is called Hypermeter ("over-measure"). The extra syllable always ends in an open vowel, which elides before an open vowel at the beginning of the next line:

cit.quote: Quos super atra silex jamjam lapsura cadentique Imminet adsimilis.
(Of the rock of Tantalus.)

div.p: Crasis, the "mixing," or coalition, of two words in one, usually with a modification of them both :
Rare in Latin, except viden' = videsne, audin' = audisne.
Synizesis, the "settling together" of two syllables in the same word into one; especially found with a "y" sound: e.g., Abiete, as a dactyl, abyětě.

div.head: Excursus 1. ATTRACTION.
div.p: The Syntax of the Concords is considerably affected by Attraction:
(1) The Concord of the Verb.
A Copulative Verb is sometimes attracted to the Number of the Predicate: cf. "the wages of sin is death":

cit.quote: Amantium irae amoris integratio est.
The quarrels of lovers are a renewal of love.

div.p: (2) The Concord of the Relative.
(a) Attraction of the Relative to the Gender and Number of the Predicate, with Copulative and Factitive Verbs:

cit.quote: Thebae, quod Boeotiae caput est.
Thebes, which is the capital of Boeotia (§ 51).

div.p: (b) Attraction of the Relative to the Case of its Antecedent:
Chiefly with the Ablative Absolute:

cit.quote: Quibus quisque poterat elatis.
Every man carrying out what he could.

div.p: Obs. Quivis, quilibet, whoever: the Relative is attracted to the Case of its Antecedent: in quivis, from the Accusative, is quem vis; in quilibet, from the Nominative, is qui libet.
(c) Attraction of the Antecedent to the Case of the Relative: "Inverse Attraction":

cit.quote: Urbem, quam statuo, vestra est.
The city which I am founding is yours.

div.p: (d) The bodily Attraction of the Antecedent into the Relative Clause (see § 138).
(3) The Concord of the Adjective and Substantive (Vocative Attraction).
The Predicate of a Copulative Verb is sometimes attracted into the Vocative of the Person addressed :

cit.quote: Macte nova virtute, puer.
Go on in thy youthful valour, O my son (sc., mactus esto).

div.p: (Many cases, however, of "Vocative Attraction" are doubtful: cf. "Or hearst thou rather, pure etherial stream" (MILTON) :

cit.quote: Matutine pater, seu Jane libentius audis.
O Father of the morning, or, O Janus, if thou wouldst be rather so addressed.)

div.p: (Note the common attraction to the Dative in names :

cit.quote: Volitans, cui nomen asilo.
An insect, whose name is asilus.)

div.head: Excursus II. SENSE CONSTRUCTION.
div.p: The Syntax of the Concords is also much affected by considerations of sense:
(1) The Concord of the Verb. A Noun of Multitude may take a Plural Verb (see § 49).
(2) The Concord of the Adjective.

cit.quote: Capita conjurationis securibus percussi sunt.
The ringleaders of the plot were beheaded.

div.p: An Adjective sometimes agrees with a Noun, especially a Pronoun, contained in another word:

cit.quote: Respublica meâ unius operâ salva erat.
The state was saved by the help of me alone.

div.p: (3) The Concord of the Substantive (Apposition).
A Substantive sometimes stands in Apposition to a Substantive contained in another word:

cit.quote: Tuum, hominis simplicis, pectus vidimus.
We have seen the heart of you, a simple man.

div.p: Apposition is often loose in kind—sometimes referring in sense to the sentence rather than to a given Noun :

cit.quote: Sed puer est, aetas mollis et apta regi.
But he (Cupid) is a boy—an age malleable and easy to control.
Ingenti subiere feretro, triste ministerium.
They shouldered the huge bier, a melancholy service.

div.p: (In such instances as the last a Neuter Noun is generally used, and the case is probably a Nominative, not an "Accusative in Apposition to the Sentence," as it is sometimes called: the Nominative being exclamatory (§ 238). But, owing to the gender, it is hard to decide the case.)
(4) The Concord of the Relative.

cit.quote: Ubi est scelus qui me perdidit?
Where is the villain who has ruined me?

div.p: (5) The Composite Subject.

cit.quote: Quibus ipse meique vescor.
Whereon I myself feed, with my family. (Sc. ipse cum meis.)
Bocchus cum peditibus aciem invadunt.
Bocchus and his infantry attack the line. (Sc. Bocchus et pedites.)

div.head: Excursus III. THE CASES.
The Nominative.

cit.quote: Audi tu, populus Albanus.
Hearken thou, people of Alba (Nominative for Vocative).

div.p: (See also Nominativus Pendens, § 522; Nominative Attraction, § 351; Nominative and Infinitive, § 179.)
div.head: The Vocative
div.p: (See Attraction, § 556).

div.head: The Accusative.
div.p: For the Direct Accusative after Intransitive Verbs used Transitively, see § 147. Note also:

cit.quote: Egressis urbem Albanis.
When the Albans had left the city.
Atilium suâ manu spargentem semen convenerunt.
They found Atilius sowing seed with his own hand.

div.p: The Direct Accusative which follows the Active is sometimes retained after the Passive:

cit.quote: Nascuntur flores inscripti nomina regum.
Flowers are born inscribed with names of kings.

div.p: (Note that the Passive Participle here conceals what would be a Dative of the Indirect Object in the Active phrase.)
The Direct Accusative sometimes follows Verbal Nouns and Adjectives:

cit.quote: Vitabundus classem hostium.
Wishing to avoid the fleet of the enemy.
Quid tibi hanc tactio est?
What do you mean by touching her?

div.p: (See also Gerund, § 184; Anticipatory Accusative, § 523.)
The Cognate Accusative may express the sphere or the effect of an action, suggest resemblance, or show the character of an action in other ways:
Equus vicit Olympia. ENN. The horse won in the Olympia.
Nec vox hominem sonat. VIRG. Nor doth thy voice sound human.
Cyclopa moveri. HOR. To dance like a Cyclops.
Resonant acalanthida dumi. VIRG. The thickets are loud with goldfinches.
Rumpere vocem. VIRG. To break into utterance.
The Adverbial Accusative is sometimes Neuter Plural:

cit.quote: Stabat acerba fremens.
He stood there in the bitterness of his rage.

div.p: A short syllable is sometimes made long in arsi, viz., if the accent of the foot falls on it (arsis, a "raising," i.e., of the voice) :
ἠέλι, ἤτοι μὲν σὺ μετ᾿ ἀθανάτοισι φάεινε.
A long syllable is sometimes made short in thesi, viz., where the accent does not fall (thesis, a "lowering," i.e., of the voice) :

cit.quote: ἀλλ᾽ ἴομεν, κεινοὺς δὲ κ.τ.λ.
(sc. ἴωμεν, let us go).

div.p: In Greek this is almost confined to δ᾽ in Tragedy, the two lines being treated as one: Synaphea, "a binding-together".
Crasis, the "mixing," or coalition, of two words in one, usually with a modification of them both :
E.g., κἀγώ = καὶ ἐγώ, τἀνδρί = τῷ ἀνδρί, θάτερον = τὸ ἕτερον.
Synizesis, the "settling together" of two syllables in the same word into one; especially found with a "y" sound: e.g., πόλεως, as an iambus, πολ-ψῶς.

div.head: Excursus 1. ATTRACTION.
div.p: The Syntax of the Concords is considerably affected by Attraction:
(1) The Concord of the Verb. A Copulative Verb is sometimes attracted to the Number of the Predicate: cf. "the wages of sin is death":

cit.quote: αἱ Θήβαι Αἴγυπτος ἐκαλεῖτο.
Thebes used to be called Egypt.

div.p: (2) The Concord of the Relative.
(a) Attraction of the Relative to the Gender and Number of the Predicate, with Copulative and Factitive Verbs:

cit.quote: ὁ φόβος, ἣν αἴδω εἴπομεν.
The fear which we called shame.

div.p: (b) Attraction of the Relative to the Case of its Antecedent:
From the Accusative, § 51 :

cit.quote: ἀμαθέστατοι ἔστε ὧν ἐγὼ οἶδα Ἑλλήνων.
You are the most ignorant of all the Greeks I know.

div.p: Obs. With οἷος this occurs even from the Nominative:

cit.quote: χαριζόμενος οἷῳ σοὶ ἀνδρί.
Doing a favour to a man like you (τοιούτῳ ἀνδρὶ, οἷος σὺ εἶ).

div.p: (c) Attraction of the Antecedent to the Case of the Relative: "Inverse Attraction":

cit.quote: τὴν οὐσίαν, ἣν κατέλιπεν, οὐ πλείονος ἀξία ἐστίν.
The inheritance, which he last left, is not worth more.

div.p: (d) The bodily Attraction of the Antecedent into the Relative Clause (see § 138).
(3) The Concord of the Adjective and Substantive (Vocative Attraction).
The Predicate of a Copulative Verb is sometimes attracted into the Vocative of the Person addressed :

cit.quote: ὄλβιε, κῶρε, γένοιο.
O boy, mayst thou be happy.

div.p: (Many cases, however, of "Vocative Attraction" are doubtful: cf. "Or hearst thou rather, pure etherial stream" (MILTON) :)

cit.quote: ἀντὶ γὰρ ἐκλήθης Ἴμβρασε Παρθενίου.
For thou wert addressed "O Imbrasus,” instead of “Parthenius”.

div.p: (Note the attraction to an Adverbial form in

cit.quote: θαυμασίως ὡς ἄθλιος.
Wonderfully wretched (viz., θαυμάσιόν ἐστιν ὡς, it is wonderful how).)

div.head: Excursus II. SENSE CONSTRUCTION.
div.p: The Syntax of the Concords is also much affected by considerations of sense:
(1) The Concord of the Verb. A Noun of Multitude may take a Plural Verb (see § 49).
(2) The Concord of the Adjective.
φίλε τέκνον. HOM. Dear child.
Common with Diminutives:

cit.quote: κολλικοφάγε Βοιωτίδιον.
Little roll-eating Bœotian.

div.p: An Adjective sometimes agrees with a Noun, especially a Pronoun, contained in another word:

cit.quote: τἀμὰ δυστήνου κακά.
The woes of me wretched. (Sc. ἐμοῦ δυστήνου.)

div.p: (3) The Concord of the Substantive (Apposition).
A Substantive sometimes stands in Apposition to a Substantive contained in another word:

cit.quote: ᾿Αθηναῖος ὤν, πόλεως τῆς μεγίστης.
Being a citizen of Athens, the greatest city.

div.p: Apposition is often loose in kind—sometimes referring in sense to the sentence rather than to a given Noun :

cit.quote: εὐδαιμονοίης, μισθὸν ἡδίστων λόγων.
May you be happy, as a reward for your good news.

div.p: (This is usually called "the Accusative in Apposition to the Sentence: strictly speaking it is half Adverbial or Cognate. More commonly there is some Noun to which the word may in grammar, however loosely, be referred; and the word differs in case accordingly: e.g.,

cit.quote: Ἑλένην κτάνωμεν, Μενέλεῳ λύπην πικράν.
Let us slay Helen, a bitter grief to Menelaus.
τῆς Σικελίας ἁπάσης, μεγάλου ἔργου, ἐφίεσθαι.
To have designs on all Sicily, an ambitious plan.)

div.p: (4) The Concord of the Relative.

cit.quote: φίλον θάλος, ὃν τέκον αὐτή.
Dear scion, whom I myself did bear.

div.p: (5) The Composite Subject.

cit.quote: ἐπύθετο τὸν Στρομβιχίδην καὶ τὰς ναῦς ἀπεληλυθότα.
He heard that Strombichides had departed with his ships.
Δημοσθένης μετὰ τῶν ξυστρατηγῶν σπεύδονται.
Demosthenes and his colleagues make all speed.

div.head: Excursus III. THE CASES.
The Nominative.

cit.quote: ὦ παῖ Πηλέως, πατήρ δ᾽ ἐμός.
O son of Peleus, father mine (Nominative for Vocative).

div.p: (See also Nominativus Pendens, § 522; Nominative Attraction, § 351; Nominative and Infinitive, § 179.)
div.head: The Vocative
div.p: (Chiefly with Relative Clauses.)

div.head: The Accusative.
div.p: For the Direct Accusative after Intransitive Verbs used Transitively, see § 147. Note also:

cit.quote: στάντες δ᾽ ὅθ᾽ αὐτοὺς οἱ τεταγμένοι βραβῆς κλήρους ἔπηλαν.
And standing where the appointed umpires had allotted them their place (κλήρους ἔπηλαν = ἔταξαν).

div.p: The Direct Accusative which follows the Active is sometimes retained after the Passive:

cit.quote: οἱ τῶν ᾿Αθηναίων ἐπιτετραμμένοι τὴν φυλακήν.
Those of the Athenians who had been entrusted with the watch.

div.p: The Direct Accusative sometimes follows Verbal Nouns and Adjectives:

cit.quote: πόλεμος ἄπορα πόριμος.
War making possible the impossible.
Σωκράτης τὰ μετέωρα φροντιστής.
Socrates, a student of the things of heaven.

div.p: (See also Verbals, § 189; Anticipatory Accusative, § 523.)
The Cognate Accusative may express the sphere or the effect of an action, suggest resemblance, or show the character of an action in other ways:
Ὀλύμπια νικᾶν. THUC. To win the Olympia.
δίκην ὀφλεῖν. DEM. To lose in a law-suit.
ψήφισμα νικᾶν. AESCHIN. To carry a decree.
βλέπειν νᾶπυ. AR. To look mustard.
ἔαρ θ᾽ ὁρῶσα Νυχεία. THEOC. Nycheia with her April eyes (A. Lang).
ῥῆξαι φωνήν. AR. To break into utterance.
The Adverbial Accusative is sometimes Neuter Plural:

cit.quote: δεινὰ δ᾽ ὑπόδρα ἰδών.
With dreadful looks askance.

div.p: (So the Superl. Adv. ῥᾷστα, etc.)
The Objective Genitive generally represents the Direct Accusative after a Verb; sometimes it is more loosely used :

cit.quote: Ira inritata deorum.
Incensed with anger against the gods.

div.p: Many instances are Greek. Note also the following:
Da noctis mediae. HOR. Pour a libation in honour of midnight (Objective, Greek: Cause).
Justitiaene prius mirer belline laborum? VIRG. Am I to admire him most for his goodness, or his toils in war? (Cause: Greek.)
Qua Daunus agrestium regnavit populorum. HOR. Where Daunus reigned over rural peoples (Objective, Greek).
Fies nobilium tu quoque fontium. HOR. You shall become (one) of noble fountains (Partitive, Greek).
Desine mollium tandem querelarum. HOR. Cease at length from unmanly plaint (Ablative, Greek).
The Possessive Genitive is sometimes emphasised by Adjectives, "peculiar to," "common to," "sacred to":
Viz., proprius, communis, sacer (sacer, also Dative):

cit.quote: Terra sacra deorum omnium est.
The earth is sacred to all the gods.

div.head: The Ablative.

cit.quote: Assiduo ruptae lectore columnae.
Columns broken by perpetual reciters (Agent, without ab, or Ablative of Cause, § 270: "perpetual recitation").

div.p: C. Fleginatem Placentia. CAES. C. Fleginas of Placentia (Origin, § 261, with Substantives).

cit.quote: Neve putes alium sapiente bonoque beatum.
And do not consider any one else than the wise and good to be happy (in Prose alius ac, Separative Ablative).
Invitum qui servat, idem facit occidenti.
Any one who preserves another against his will, does the same as if he killed him (Indirect Dative).
It clamor coelo.
A cry goes up to heaven (Dative of Motion to: Poetic).
Carmina quae scribuntur aquae potoribus.
Poems written by water-drinkers (Dat. of Agent, § 287).
Quibus volentibus bellum erat.
Who wished for war? (lit., "to whom, not wishing it," Greek).

div.p: Note. Scribo ad te is more common than scribo tibi.

Note.—The "Dative of the Thing" is used with (a) the Verb to be (§ 288); (b) Verbs of imputing, e.g., Vitio vertere alicui, to impute as a fault to any one; (c) Verbs of going, sending, giving, with auxilio, praesidio, subsidio. Sometimes with Substantives, e.g.,

cit.quote: Signum receptui.
The signal for retreat.

div.p: On its use with Gerunds and Gerundives, see § 600.

Note 1.—The Plain Ablative of Place Where is used (a) with the words parte, regione, loco, dextra, laeva, medio, terra marique; (b) in the sense of "on" or "over," with an epithet, especially medius and totus.
Other instances are probably Instrumental (§ 266), e.g., manu tenens, holding in (viz., with) the hand, or of the Road by which, e.g., Missa Pado (VIRG.), sped down the Po.
(In Poetry there is some licence, but not in the sense of "in".)
Note 2.—Domus, when qualified, may have a Preposition: e.g.,

cit.quote: In domum veterem e novâ.
From a new house to an old one.

div.p: Notice the combination:

cit.quote: Milites Albae constiterunt, in urbe opportuna.
The troops halted at Alba, a convenient city.

div.p: In Poetry the Preposition is sometimes omitted, where we should expect one, of Place Where, Whither, Whence :
(1) Italiam venit. VIRG. He came to Italy.
(2) Carceribus missos currus. VIRG. Cars sped from the barriers.
(3) Pagasaeis collibus. OV. On Pagasæan hills.

div.head: Excursus IV. THE MOODS.
Indicative, Imperative, Conjunctive.

cit.quote: Pollio amat nostram, quamvis est rustica, Musam.
Pollio loves my Muse, though she is but a country-maid.

div.p: (Quamvis with Indicative; frequent in Poetry, § 441.)

cit.quote: Tityre, dum redeo, brevis est via, pasce capellas.
Feed my she-goats till I return.
Dum fugeret, hydrum non vidit.
While flying from thee she saw not the serpent.

div.p: (Dum redeo perhaps "while I am on my way back," viz., dum absum, purely temporal (§ 424); dum fugeret perhaps really purpose—in her hurry to escape (§ 426).)

cit.quote: Rediit paullo post quod se oblitum nescio quid diceret.
He returned shortly after, because he said he had forgotten something.

div.p: (Subjunctive of Virtual Or. Obl. (§ 476) transferred to Verb of speaking itself (§ 410).)
Ut ne is used sometimes for ne in Final Clauses:

cit.quote: Ad me velim scribas, ut prorsus ne quid ignorem.
I should like you to write to me that I may not be utterly ignorant of anything.
Quemcunque lictor prehendisset, tribunus mitti jubebat.
Whomever the lictor seized the tribune would order to be set free.

div.p: (Prehendisset, Frequentative Conjunctive: Greek. Latin generally uses the Perfects Indicative (§ 217).)

cit.quote: Quid, si hostes ad urbem veniant, facturi estis?
What would you do if the enemy were to come to the city? (Facturi estis, periphrasis for faciatis, § 402.)
Si fractus illabatur orbis, impavidum ferient ruinae.
If the earth should crack and crumble away, the blow of ruin will leave him undismayed (vivid Future Indicative, § 406).
Solus eram, si non saevus adesset amor.
I was alone, had not cruel love been with me (Vivid Indicative, § 406).
Et faceret, si non aera repulsa sonent.
And would do so, did not the clashing cymbals sound. (Tibullus often uses this irregular combination of primary and historic.)
Delitui dum vela darent, si forte dedissent.
I lay hid till they should sail, in case they should do so (= in Oratio Recta, si forte dederint, effugiam).

div.head: Commands:

cit.quote: At tu dictis, Albane, maneres.
You should have abided by your words, O man of Alba.
Quid facere debuisti? Frumentum ne emisses, sumpsisses id nummorum.
What ought you to have done? You ought not to have bought the corn, you ought to have taken that amount of money.

div.p: (Maneres, emisses, sumpsisses are Past Jussive.)
Observe, moreover, the following ways of expressing a Direct Command, beside those given § 330:
(a) Present Subjunctive (you = anyone, vague): audias; ne audias.
(b) Future Indicative (strong command, "thou shalt"): audies; non audies.
(c) Imperative in -to (legal): audito; ne audito.
(On cura, cave, see § 370.)

Remark.—The Primary and Historic Sequence are sometimes found combined, especially in long Oratio Obliqua, either for variety or for the sake of vividness. This is very common in Cæsar, even after a Historic Tense: e.g., B. G., i., 14: Cæsar respondit...quod teneret...quominus...intulerint...accidissent. Cum sint...quas si...satisfaciant.
So in Final Clauses, sometimes for variety, sometimes to distinguish the nearer consequence from the more remote :

cit.quote: Mago nuntios Carthaginem ad senatum mittit, qui hortentur ut auxilia mitterent.
Mago sent messengers to the senate at Carthage to exhort them to send further help.

div.head: Excursus V. INFINITIVE AND PARTICIPLE.
The Infinitive.
div.p: The Infinitive as a Noun:

cit.quote: Hoc ridere meum nullâ tibi vendo Iliade.
This laugh of mine I will not sell you for an Iliad.
Inter optime valere et gravissime aegrotare nihil prorsus dicunt interesse.
They say there is no difference whatever between the best of health and serious illness.

div.p: (Not usually qualified by an Attribute, hoc, meum; with Prepositions the Gerund is usual.)

div.head: The Genitive.
div.p: The Objective Genitive generally represents the Direct Accusative after a Verb; sometimes it is more loosely used :

cit.quote: τὸ τῶν Μεγαρέων ψήφισμα.
The decree about the Megarians.
σπεῖσον ἀγαθοῦ δαίμονος.
Pour libation in honour of the good genius (Cause, § 256).
ὦ δυσθέατον ὄμμα καὶ τόλμης πικρᾶς.
O sight cruel and of fatal rashness (Quality, § 247).

div.p: μέγα χρῆμα συός. HDT. A monster of a boar (Definition).

cit.quote: βέβασιν ἄρτι δωμάτων ὑπόστεγοι.
They have just passed within the shelter of the house (Genitive after Substantive contained in ὑπόστεγοι).
ἀλλ᾽ ἔστι τοῦ λέγοντος, ἢν φόβους λέγῃ.
But is swayed by the speaker, if he counsel fear (Possessive, § 239).

div.p: The Possessive Genitive is sometimes emphasised by Adjectives, "peculiar to," "common to," "sacred to":
Viz., οἰκεῖος, ἴδιος, κοινός, ἱερός (all these also, Dative):

cit.quote: γῆ ἱερὰ πάντων θεῶν.
The earth is sacred to all the gods.

div.p: Note the Gen. of Ablation in:

cit.quote: κεῖσαι σᾶς ἀλόχου σφαγεὶς Αἰγίσθου τε.
Thou liest slain by thy wife and Ægisthus (Agent without ὕπο; but many instances are half Comparative, e.g., after ἡσσάομαι).

div.p: Occasionally the Genitive Absolute is expressed by two Nouns (cf. Latin Abl. Abs.) :

cit.quote: ὄρνις ὧν ὑφηγητῶν ἐγὼ κτενεῖν ἔμελλον πατέρα τὸν ἐμόν.
The birds by whose augury I was to slay my father.
τὸν αὐτὸν χῶρον ἐκλιπὼν ἐμοί.
Leaving the same place as I. (On the analogy of ὅμοιος: usually ὁ αὐτὸς καί.)
πολλὰς δ᾽ ἰφθίμους ψυχὰς Ἄϊδι προΐαψεν.
And many a brave spirit did he hurl to Hell (Dative of Motion to: half recipience, Hades being also a person: but cf. ποῖ, whither (?)).
τῷ πλήθει τῶν Πλαταιῶν οὐ βουλομένῳ ἦν τῶν ᾿Αθηναίων ἀφίστασθαι.
The populace of Platæa did not wish to revolt from the Athenians (Dative of Interest).

div.p: Note. The Dative of Interest is not infrequently used with Participles, as above: lit., "to revolt was not to them wishing it," viz., not in accordance with their wishes. It is also used absolutely: e.g.,
ὡς γ᾽ ἐμοὶ κριτῇ. In my judgment.

cit.quote: συνελόντι εἰπεῖν.
To speak briefly (Absolute Infinitive, § 176: also συνελόντι alone, without the Infinitive).

div.p: Note. A Genitive of Place Where sometimes occurs in Poetry. The Genitive must be here considered as expressing an antecedent condition from which the notion of the Verb originates (cf. the Genitive with πρός and with ἀκούω): e.g.,

cit.quote: ἐσχάτης ὁρῶ πυρᾶς νεωρῆ βόστρυχον τετμημένον.
On the edge of the pyre I behold a lock of new-cut hair.

div.p: So of Place over which":

cit.quote: ἡμερεύοντας ξένους μακρᾶς κελεύθου.
Strangers spending the day on a long journey.

div.p: (The following Prose instances are either Partitive, Possessive, or of Respect: ἐπετάχυνον τῆς ὁδοῦ. THUC. They hurried them on their way. (Part.) Οἰνόη τῆς Ἀττικῆς. THUC. Oenoe (of) in Attica. (Possess.) προκόπτειν τῆς ἀρχῆς (THUC.), "in respect of," or after πρό.)
In Poetry the Preposition is sometimes omitted, where we should expect one, of Place Where, Whither, Whence :
(1) πύργους ἔπλευσε. EUR. She sailed to the towers.
(2) νεὼς ἄγοντα. SOPH. Bringing from the ship.
(3) μέγας οὐράνῳ Ζεύς. SOPH. Zeus is great in heaven.

div.head: Excursus IV. THE MOODS.
Indicative, Imperative, Conjunctive.

cit.quote: ἀνωλόλυξε πρίν γ᾽ ὁρᾷ.
She cried out before she saw.

div.p: (After a Positive πρίν usually takes a vague Infinitive, § 429: the Indicative here marks an actual fact.)

cit.quote: ἡδέως ἂν Καλλικλεῖ διελεγόμην, ἕως ἀπέδωκα.
I would gladly have conversed with Callicles till I had repaid it.

div.p: (ἕως, Indefinite, with the Indicative. The Optative would be usual (§ 426).)
The Relative with Subjunctive of Purpose (cf. Latin):

cit.quote: πρέσβεις ἄγουσα οἵπερ φράσωσιν.
Conveying ambassadors who were to announce (§ 462).

div.p: ὅπως with Future Indicative of Purpose: poetic (§385):

cit.quote: θέλγει ὅπως Ἰθάκης ἐπιλήσεται.
She charms him so that he shall forget Ithaca.

div.p: The Future Indicative used like the Present and Aorist Indicative (§ 372) of a fear that amounts to a belief or opinion:

cit.quote: φοβοῦμαι μὴ εὑρήσομεν.
I am afraid that we shall find.

div.p: On the omission of ἄν with Subjunctive after ἕως, πρίν, μέχρι, see § 217. Note also the poetic usages with ὅς:

cit.quote: γέροντα δ᾽ ὀρθοῦν φλαῦρον, ὃς νέος πέσῃ.
'Tis an idle thing to uplift in old age a man who falls in youth.

div.head: Conditionals:

cit.quote: ἡ πόλις ἐκινδύνευσε πᾶσα διαφθαρῆναι, εἰ ἄνεμος ἐπεγένετο.
The city was in danger of being destroyed, had a wind sprung up (ἐκινδ. διαφ., periphrasis for διεφθάρη ἄν, § 402).
δυστάλαινα τἄρ᾽ ἐγὼ, εἴ σου στερηθῶ.
Unhappy then am I, if I am to be deprived of thee (probably deliberative, suggesting the question, ἆρά σου στερηθῶ; Am I to be deprived? (§ 396)).
εἰ θέλοιμεν σκοπεῖν τὰς φύσεις τὰς τῶν ἀνθρώπων, εὑρήσομεν.
If we cared to consider the natures of men we shall find (Irregular combination of Protasis in B with Apodosis in A, § 398).
εἰ γὰρ οὗτοι ὀρθῶς ἀπέστησαν, ὑμεῖς ἂν οὐ χρεὼν ἄρχοιτε.
If these had a right to secede, it follows that your empire would be unjust (= συμβαίνει ὥστε, εἰ χρεὼν πράττοιτε, οὐκ ἂν ἄρχοιτε).

div.p: Ν.Β.—πῶς ἂν θάνοιμι; would I could die: a Wish.

div.head: Commands:

cit.quote: φέρ᾽, ὦ τέκνον, μάθῃς.
Come, my son, learn.

div.p: μὴ φεῦσον ἐλπίδος. ARIST. Balk me not of my hope.

cit.quote: μήδ᾽ ἡ βία σε νικησάτω.
Let not force o'ercome thee.

div.p: (The Subjunctive is rare of a Positive Command, the Aorist Imperative of a Negative Command (§ 330), though less so in the Third Person.)
Observe, moreover, the following ways of expressing a Direct Command, beside those given § 330:
(a) Optative with ἄν (polite): λέγοις ἄν, kindly speak (Neg. οὐ).
(b) Future Indicative statement (thou shalt): ποιήσεις, οὐ ποιήσεις.
(c) Imperative in -to (legal): question with οὐ and οὐ μή (§ 516).
(On ὅπως with Fut. Ind. see § 370.)

Remark.—The Primary and Historic Sequence are sometimes found combined, especially in Oratio Obliqua, sometimes for variety, sometimes with a difference in sense—the Indicative expressing the more certain or more important fact:

cit.quote: οὗτοι ἔλεγον ὅτι Κῦρος μὲν τέθνηκεν, ᾿Αριαῖος δὲ πεφευγὼς ἐν τῷ σταθμῷ εἴη.
They said that Cyrus was dead and that Ariæus had fled and was in the camp.

div.p: So in Final Clauses, sometimes for variety, sometimes to distinguish the nearer consequence from the more remote :

cit.quote: παρανῖσχον δὲ φρυκτοὺς, ὅπως ἀσαφῆ τὰ σημεῖα τοῖς πολεμίοις ἢ καὶ μὴ βοηθοῖεν.
They displayed beacons that the enemy might be confused as to the signals, and so might not come to the rescue.

div.head: Excursus V. INFINITIVE AND PARTICIPLE.
The Infinitive.
div.p: The Infinitive as a Noun:

cit.quote: αὐτὸ μὲν γὰρ τὸ ἀποθνήσκειν οὐδεὶς φοβεῖται.
For of mere dying no one is afraid.
ἀντὶ μὲν δούλων ἐποίησας ἐλευθέρους Πέρσας εἶναι, ἀντὶ δὲ ἄρχεσθαι ὑπ᾿ ἄλλων, ἄρχειν ἁπάντων.
You made the Persians to rule all instead of being ruled by others.

div.p: (No other word but αὐτό can qualify an Infinitive; after Prepositions the Article τό is usually prefixed.)

body.head: IV. APPENDIX TO SYNTAX.

div.p:
Poetic Infinitives, where Prose would use ut and Subjunctive:
Stabant orantes primi transmittere cursum. VIRG. They stood there praying to be the first to cross.
Impulerat ferro Argolicas foedare latebras. VIRG. He had driven us to probe the hiding-place of the Argives with our swords.

Legati veniunt speculari. LIV. Ambassadors come to reconnoitre.
Proteus pecus egit altos visere montes. HOR. Proteus drove his flock to visit the high mountains.
(Here transmittere and foedare are less noticeable, owing to the ordinary Prolative Infinitive after cupio and cogo (§§ 357, 366); speculari and visere are the more irregular as expressing separate purpose (§ 384).)
With Substantives and Adjectives: see § 177.

Notice also Amor cognoscere (VIRG.), desire to know; Prose, cognoscendi. Cantari dignus (VIRG.), worthy to be sung; Prose, qui cantetur (§ 465). And the Greek Infinitives: Blandus ducere (HOR.), cunning at leading; Niveus videri (HOR.), snowy to look upon (Epexegetic). Horace is specially fond of these.

div.head: NOTES ON THE MOODS.
The Participle.

div.p:
The Neuter Participle is sometimes used practically as a Substantive:
Notumque furens quid femina possit. VIRG. And the knowledge of what a frenzied woman can do.
So also Ante expectatum (VIRG.), before it could be expected (sc. antequam expectari posset).

Ablative Absolute without a Noun:
Excepto quod non simul esses, caetera laetus. HOR. Except for the fact that you were not with me, happy in all else.
(So also in the phrases, Explorato, after exploring; augurato, the auguries being taken; necopinato, contrary to expectation, etc.: these are frequent in Livy.)

Note. The Supplementary Participle occurs commonly in Latin with certain Verbs, e.g., video, audio, nuntio, invenio, see § 198; in Poetry its use goes further. With both the Participle and the Infinitive the Nominative Attraction is found in Poetry, in imitation of the Greek:
Sensit medios delapsus in hostes. VIRG. He felt him fallen into the midst of foes.
Phaselus ille ait fuisse navium celerrimus. CATUL. That pinnace avows that he was once the swiftest of ships.
(Note also Gaudent perfusi sanguine fratrum (VIRG.), they rejoice to be bedewed in a brother's blood; ne falleret incedens (LIV.), lest he should march undiscovered; fallit sorte beatior (Hor.), sc. λανθάνει ὀλβιωτέρα οὖσα τῇ τύχῃ, lit., escapes his notice being happier in its lot: all of which are imitations of the Supplementary Participle in Greek.)

div.head: The Tenses of the Infinitive and Participle (§ 216).

div.p:
The want of a Present Participle Passive and Past Participle Active led to some irregularities:
Prae se actam praedam ostentantes. LIV. Showing the booty they were driving before them.
Eum prius incertis implicantes responsis. LIV. Having first involved him in ambiguous answers.
(The first—the use of the Past Participle Passive as a Present—is common; the other rarer.)

The Infinitive with Verbs of Command, etc., is sometimes preceded by ὥστε (§ 355):
οὐ γὰρ ἔπειθε τοὺς Χίους ὥστε ἑωυτῷ δοῦναι νέας. HDT. For he did not persuade the Chians to give him ships.

So the Prolative Infinitive has sometimes the Article:
τὸ δρᾶν οὐκ ἠθέλησαν. SOPH. They did not wish to do it.

So the Absolute Infinitive (§ 176):
τὸ ἐπὶ σφᾶς εἶναι. THUC. So far as they were concerned.

The Infinitive sometimes expresses purpose:
μανθάνειν γὰρ ἥκομεν. SOPH. For we are come to learn.

The Subject of the Absolute Infinitive of Command is generally Accusative, as the Object of, e.д., κελεύω (§ 176); sometimes it is Vocative or Nominative, ἔθελε being understood:
ὦ ξεῖν, ἀγγέλλειν Λακεδαιμονίοις. SIMON. Stranger, go tell the Spartans.

The Epexegetic Infinitive sometimes explains Substantives (§ 183):
χρυσήλατον γὰρ ἄνδρα τευχηστὴν ἰδεῖν. AESCH. A warrior to look upon, in golden armour clad.

div.head: NOTES ON THE MOODS.
The Participle.

div.p:
καὶ αὐτῷ ἔτι ῥώμην καὶ ἡ νῆσος ἐμπρηθεῖσα παρέσχε. THUC. The conflagration of the island also helped him further.
(Sc. τὸ τὴν νῆσον ἐμπρηθῆναι, cf. Latin, Caesar occisus. So μετὰ Σολῶνα οἰχόμενον (HDT.), after Solon's departure; ἐς ἥλιον καταδύντα, to sunset.)
Note the Neuters in Thucydides: τὸ θαρσοῦν, the confident party; τὸ δεδιὸς αὐτοῦ, the fact that he was afraid.

Note, beside δέον, etc., the Accusative Absolute, εἰρημένον, γεγραμμένον, δυνατὸν ὄν. (The Accusative Absolute never has a Substantive: e.g., φόνον λύοντας, ὡς τόδ' αἷμα χείμαζον πόλιν SOPH. atoning for the murder, as it is this deed of blood that troubles the city ; αἷμα is in Apposition to φόνον.)

Note.-Verbs that commonly take the Participle are sometimes found with the Infinitive, and vice versa (§§ 348, 350), when either class approaches the other in sense:
ἀλλ᾽ ἴσθι τοι τὰ σκλήρ᾽ ἄγαν φρονήματα πίπτειν μάλιστα. SOPH. But know that too proud spirits most often fall.
πότερόν σε φῶμεν σπουδάζοντα ἢ παίζοντα; PLAT. Are we to conceive of you as being in earnest or jesting?
(Cf. English, "I saw him run"—I saw him running.)

Sometimes the Accusative is used of the Subject of the Main Verb:
Κροῖσος ἐνόμισε ἑωυτὸν εἶναι ὀλβιώτατον HDT. .
Note the omission of the Participle in εἰδὼς εὐτρεπεῖς ἡμᾶς (DEM., 45); νῦν δ᾽ ἀγροῖσι τυγχάνει (SOPH., El., 313).

Note ἄν with Participle:
χωρὶς τῆς περιστάσης ἂν ἡμᾶς αἰσχύνης, εἰ καθυφείμεθά τι τῶν πραγμάτων. DEM. Apart from the disgrace which would attach to us, if we were to let go any of our interests.

div.head: The Tenses of the Infinitive and Participle (§ 216).

div.p:
The want of a separate Participle and Infinitive for the Imperfect led to some irregularities:
τίνας ποτ᾿ εὐχὰς ὑπολαμβάνετ᾽ εὔχεσθαι τὸν Φίλιππον, ὅτ᾽ ἔσπενδεν; DEM. What prayers do you think Philip was offering when he was pouring libation?
οἱ συμπρεσβεύοντες καὶ παρόντες καταμαρτυρήσουσιν. DEM. Those who were his colleagues, and who were present at the time, will witness against him.

With memini the Present Infinitive is often Imperfect:
Ego Metellum memini puer bonis esse viribus. CIC. I remember as a boy that Metellus was hale and strong.

Poenarum solvendi tempus. LUCR. Time for payment of penalty.
(Gerund as pure Substantive, solutionis; used partly to avoid the double -arum.)

Germanicus Aegyptum proficiscitur cognoscendae antiquitatis. TAC. Germanicus set out for Egypt with the object of studying its antiquities
(Greek Genitive of Purpose: τοῦ γιγνώσκειν, § 186).

Observe the Gerund and Gerundive expressing the Dative of the Thing (§ 288):
Solvendo non erat Magius. CIC. Magius was insolvent (lit., was not for paying).
Xviri agris dandis dividundis. A commission of ten men for the assignment and distribution of land.
Dedit huic aetas vires onerique ferendo est. Ov. Age has given him strength and he is (fit) for bearing burdens.
(The phrase solvendo esse is common; so too is the Gerundive in official phrases after Substantives, Xviri, etc.; the Gerundive with esse, as in the last instance, is rare.)
The Gerundive is sometimes used as a Present Participle Middle: e.g., Volvendis mensibus VIRG., A., i., 269 with revolving months (cf. volventibus annis, in the same book, 234).

Transitive use of the Gerund of Obligation: Poetic, cf. Greek Verbals in -τέον, § 189:
Aeternas quoniam poenas in morte timendum est. LUCR. Since we must fear eternal pains in death.
Note 1. Apparently Passive use of the Gerund: due to the detachment of the Gerund from the Subject of the Main Verb. Observe the stages:

cit.quote: Caesar oppidum ad diripiendum militibus concessit.
Caesar handed the town over to his soldiers to pillage.

list.item:
Audendo atque agendo res Romana crevit. LIV. The power of Rome grew through courage and energy
(Gerund as Abstract Noun).

Ulcus enim vivescit et inveterascit alendo. LUCR. For a wound quickens and grows old by being nurtured
(really, “by one's nurturing it"; "by nurture," alimento.)

div.p: Note 2. The Gerundive grew out of the Gerund from several reasons combined:

list.item: The frequent detachment of the Gerund from the Subject, obscuring the Active character of the Gerund.

The frequent importance of the Object of the Gerund, as contrasted with the Gerund itself: e.g., instead of, legatos miserunt pacem petendi causâ, we might say, with little loss to the sense, pacis causâ.
The awkwardness of having two words, a Main Verb and a Verbal Noun, in the same sentence, both governing an Accusative.
The half Adjectival termination of the Gerund, resembling a Participle in -ens, -entis, or an Adj. in -undus.

div.p: As a result, the construction was thrown on to the Object of the Gerund; and the Gerund itself, a Substantive and Active, was drawn into agreement as an Adjective and Passive: viz., became a Gerundive. This process is called "Gerundival Attraction".

Note 3. The Gerund and Gerundive as expressing Obligation. — Just as Opus est mihi, there is a work for me, came to mean "there is a work for me to be done"; so, e.g., operandum est mihi, "there is some working for me," came to have a sense of Obligation. And once this sense attached to the Gerund, it soon attached to the Gerundive, which had grown out of the Gerund.
IV. APPENDIX TO SYNTAX. Observe that this account explains also the use of the Dative of the Agent commonly used with the Gerund and Gerundive of Obligation: viz., it is a Dative of Interest. And the Dative, thus used for agency with the Gerund and Gerundive, was afterwards so used with the Passive Participles, as being most akin to the Gerundive; and, finally, its original character being forgotten, came also to be used even with Finite Verbs (§576).

note.p: (See Roby, Vol. II., p. lxi sqq.: from which the above is mainly drawn.)

div.p:
With μέμνημαι and οἶδα this last is frequent:
μέμνημαι δὲ ἔγωγε καὶ παῖς ὢν Κριτίᾳ τῷδε ξυνόντα σε. PLAT. I remember as a boy your consorting with Critias here.

div.head: οὐ μή (§ 517).

div.p:
Other instances of οὐ μή expressing prohibition are:
οὐ σῖγ᾽ ἀνέξει, μηδὲ δειλίαν ἀρεῖ; SOPH. Keep silent, and do not be a coward (sc. οὐ μὴ ἀρεῖ).
οὐ μὴ λαλήσεις, ἀλλ᾽ ἀκολουθήσεις ἐμοί; AR. Prate not, but follow me (sc., οὐκ ἀκολουθήσεις).

οὐ μή, of denial, may be represented in Oratio Obliqua by the Future Infinitive or Optative:
σαφῶς γὰρ εἶπε Τειρεσίας οὐ μή ΠΟΤΕ σοῦ τήνδε γῆν οἰκοῦντος εὖ πράξειν πόλιν. EUR. Teiresias clearly said that while you inhabited this land the state could never prosper.
τὰ δ᾽ ἄλλα πάντ᾽ ἐθέσπισεν καὶ τἀπὶ Τροίας πέργαμ᾽ ὡς οὐ μή ΠΟΤΕ πέρσοιεν, εἰ μὴ τόνδ᾽ ἄγοιντο. SOPH. He prophesied all else, and that
div.head: IV. APPENDIX TO SYNTAX.

p.quote: they would never sack the towers of Troy, unless they brought this man.

div.p: Note. MSS. have been arbitrarily altered to suit the distinction of denial and prohibition, but both constructions are found with either force and probably admit of one explanation.
Three explanations are possible:

item.p: That there is an ellipse of δέος ἐστί between οὐ and μή. This explains denial, and is supported by, e.g., οὐ φόβος μή σε ἀγάγω ΧΕN., Mem., ii., 1. 25 . But explanations by ellipse are suspicious; it is inadequate for Prohibitions with οὐ μή, and does not touch those with οὐ alone.

That οὐ μή is one strong Negative and the phrase a Statement. This explains denial and fuller prohibitions, e.g., οὐ μὴ προσοίσεις. But there is no evidence of the redundancy of different Negatives οὐ and μή; and this,
NOTES ON THE MOODS. like the first, does not touch οὐκ ἀνέξει. Both these explanations, in fact, require a different explanation for the separate Negatives οὐ σῖγ᾽ ἀνέξει and μηδὲ ἀρεῖ : e.g., as two separate questions in which οὐ = nonne and μή = num.

That οὐ μή was in its origin interrogative. This starts with the advantage of recognising the parallelism between οὐ ποιήσεις, a Command, and οὐ μὴ ποιήσεις, a Prohibition; and covers Prohibitions generally. It covers Denials also, if we suppose an original connexion between the Aorist Subjunctive as a mild Future and the Future Indicative—a supposition necessary also to explanation (2): though in (3) it is not even necessary, for the Subjunctive may, as a Question, be Deliberative. Thus οὐ μὴ μεθέψομαι; “shall I not decline to follow?”; οὐ μὴ παύσωμαι; "shall I not decline" or "am I not to decline to cease?"; viz., “I will not follow," "I will not cease". With regard to Denials in Oratio Obliqua, we must suppose that the phrase
IV. APPENDIX TO SYNTAX. had become stereotyped and its Interrogative character obscured. One point remains. If the two idioms were the same in origin, how was it they came to differ, as they do as a rule, in meaning? Probably this is due to the inherent differences of Mood and Person, the Future Indicative being stronger than the Aorist Subjunctive, and the Second Person being naturally the Person of Command; viz., the two differ like the English "shall" and "will": "shall I not stop fighting?" = "I will not fight," Denial; "will you not stop fighting?" = "do not fight," Prohibition. And just as for the last we might sometimes say "shall you not stop fighting?" so the Aorist Subjunctive might sometimes, though rarely, be used for Prohibition:
οὐ μὴ σκώψῃς ἀλλ᾽ εὐφήμει. AR. Do not scoff, but keep quiet!
